abstract.p: Trout Unlimited Croton Watershed chapter past president Larry Boutis letter holds July 9 article fails to mention that Gov George Pataki informed organization by letter more than two years ago that Westchester stream reclassification would take place within a year (S)

block.p: In the article ''Pollution Police, Armed With Fly Rods'' [Westchester section, July 9], Jennifer Post, a state spokeswoman is cited, who claims the reason Westchester stream reclassification is taking such a long time is because it is a complicated and expensive process.

The article fails to mention that Gov. George E. Pataki informed members of the Croton Watershed Chapter of Trout Unlimited by official letter (the current president, John Keane, has the original copy) more than two years ago that the said stream classification would take place within the year.

The article fails to mention that Gov. George E. Pataki informed members of the Croton Watershed Chapter of Trout Unlimited by official letter (the current president, John Keane, has the original copy) more than two years ago that the said stream classification would take place within the year.
Also, Ms. Post is presumably aware of the fact that upstate watersheds, which are much more watered, were reclassified years ago.

Could it be that some stand to gain in this political procrastination? Perhaps one need look no further than those who continue to pollute our local rivers and streams, and those in the state who make little effort to stop them?
LARRY BOUTIS Past President Croton Watershed Chapter Trout Unlimited Briarcliff Manor
